section.title: Requirements
section.para: Before you can compile AbacusCM you need the following pieces of software installed:

listitem.para: g++ (3.3, 3.4 and 4.4 have all worked at various times).
Qt 3 (only required for the GUI client).
MySQL 4.1 or later (only required for the server). In theory any RDB could work, but currently only MySQL is supported.
GNU make. The build process uses patterns and other features only supported by GNU make.

section.title: Compiling
section.para: If you want to compile everything, just run make.

If you only want to compile certain components, copy Makefile.conf.sample to Makefile.conf and edit it (there are details in the file). From here you should be able to run make and only get what you want.

section.title: Generating certificates
section.para: Abacus uses X.509 certificates to allow clients to check that they are connecting to a genuine server, and have not been subjected to a man-in-the-middle attack. To run a contest, you will need a certificate authority (CA) certificate, and a certificate per server signed by that certificate authority.

Note that at present, the client will happily connect to any server that has a certificate signed by the CA. You should thus not have your server certificates signed by a public CA, as anyone else whose certificate has been signed by that CA would be able to accept connections from clients. Instead, you should generate your own CA certificate, and distribute cacert.crt to the clients (see ).
To create the CA certificate, enter the certs directory and run

This will run for a while and then prompt for some details, you can mostly just fill in here whatever you want. Be warned though that Server Name isn't exactly what you expect it to be. This is the CN field, and should probably be something like AbacusCM CA.

Once you have created the CA certificate, you need to create a certificate for each server. Theoretically this could be done using certificate requests but this has not been implemented yet as ssh has proven adequate for distributing certificates securely.
To create a key for a server you should use the addserver.sh script (in certs. This script takes a single parameter, the name of the certificate (usually a short name for the server) e.g.,

This will create a key and a certificate request for pug and then proceed to sign that request with the previously generated CA. Again, you can enter just about any details when prompted. You should however, enter the fully qualified domain name when asked for Server name (the name that users of the AbacusCM client will enter when connecting to the server). Also be sure to enter a State or Province Name or it will fail.
When the script is done it will symlink the keys and certificates into certs as servername.crt and servername.key. You will need to set up the server configuration file to reference them (see ).

section.title: Configuring the client
section.para: Running the abacuscm client requires three things:

listitem.para: A certificate used to sign the servers. Contestant administrators should refer to for information about generating certificates. Anyone else configuring a client should ask the contest administrator for the certificate.

A configuration file. There is a sample configuration file in conf/client.conf.sample. The client will look for configuration in the following places (if more than one is found, settings in later files override those in earlier files):
There are two settings you may need to change from the example configuration file:
Change address to the hostname of the default abacuscm server.

Change cacert to the path to the certificate. Using an absolute path is more robust, as a relative path will be interpreted relative to the working directory from which abacus was started, rather than the configuration file.

section.para: The script misc/installclient.sh will install bin/abacus to /usr/local/bin and the sample configuration file to /etc/abacus/client.conf. You can run this as root to install for all users. It is suggested that if you do this, you place the certificate at /etc/abacus/cacert.crt, but this is purely a convention.
Of course, it is also possible to run the client directly from the source directory.

section.title: Preparing the database
section.para: Each server needs its own database. Currently only MySQL is supported as a database backend. The minimal set of privileges is not currently known, and so currently all privileges are given to the database user.
Assuming the MySQL server is running on localhost, you can create the database as follows:

screen.userinput: grant all privileges on abacus.* \ to abacus@localhost identified by 'password';

section.title: Server configuration file
section.para: You should use the default configuration file (conf/server.conf.sample) as a starting point. You should change the following settings:

step.para: Change the settings in the [mysql] section to match the details of your MySQL server and the account created in .
In the [clientlistener] section, change the x509 and private options to the server certificate and private key (see ).
In the [initialisation] section, make sure the type is master, and that the name matches the parameter passed to addserver.sh.

Set admin_password to a password that the contest administrator will use. Note that this only takes effect the first time the server is started. After that, the password is stored in the database, and this setting has no effect. It need not be the same as the database password.
In the [init_attribs] section, set ip to the IP address of the server.

section.title: Configuring the markers
section.para: The simplest way to install a marker is to run misc/installmarker.sh (this requires you to be root, and then edit the configuration file. Note that the installation process will create a group called markerd and a setuid binary called runlimit that is executable by this group.
The marker will need an Abacus account. You can create one though the GUI (using the admin account, or you can use the command-line adduser tool:

screen.userinput: bin/adduser abacus.conf admin adminpass \ marker1 "Marker A" markpass marker

section.para: There are several configuration file options you will need to change:

step.para: In the [server] section, configure address and cacert as described in . Also set the username and password to the Abacus marker account. You can use the same account for several marker machines, but troubleshooting will be easier if each marker machine uses its own account.
In the [compilers], [java] and [python] sections, configure the paths to the compilers and interpreters. The [java] policy must point at the policy file provided with the abacuscm source bundle.

In the [marker] section, the workdir is used as the argument to mkdtemp. If the marker has lots of spare memory, it would make sense to use a tmpfs filesystem. Additionally, runlimit must be set to the path to the runlimit binary.

section.para: The marker can be run under a normal user account, as long as that user is in the markerd group. Since members of this group can run the runlimit setuid binary, only trusted users should be placed in this group.
Once everything is configured, the marker is started by running

This will connect to the server and mark solutions. If the connection fails, it will automatically reconnect to the server. If the file /etc/abacus/marker.conf exists, it is used to obtain options regardless of whether a configuration file is provided on the command-line. If both are present, options in the command-line configuration file take precedence.

The marker is designed to have only one instance running on a system. It is possible to run multiple instances by using a different configuration file for each instance, with different users and groups (to prevent marked solutions from interfering with each other). This is not recommended, as solutions undergoing evaluation may contend for memory bandwidth or CPU execution units, making timing less accurate.

section.title: Online standings
section.para: The standings is used to generate standings that can be viewed from a web browser, with automatic updates. To set this up, follow these steps:

step.para: Copy misc/standings/standings.pl to a cgi-bin directory (if you have the rights to do so).
Tweak the settings at the top of standings.pl.
Copy the other files from misc/standings to a normal web server directory.
Make any tweaks to standings.html standings.css to your taste (leave in the magic HTML comments, which are used by the Perl script to fill in content).
where /www-data is the directory where the files were placed in . If the filename is omitted, it will write to standings.txt in the current directory.

This will prompt you for a username and passwork to connect to the server. You can use any account, but the standings display will be whatever that account is authorised. Thus, if you want the online standings to reflect the contestants' view, use a dummy contestant account.

section.para: You can now point a web browser at either standings.pl or standings.html. The former requires CGI, but has the advantage that it will work even without Javascript enabled (but will not auto-update or have any nice animations). If you use standings.pl file, then standings.html is needed only to provide a template.

note.para: The files in misc/standings/js are third-party and contains their own licenses.

The complete error message would read:
ack_id == 0 cannot possibly be correct. This could potentially happen if/when a server did not initialise properly upon first creation (the first PeerMessage a server receives must be its own initialisation message. Please see the administrator's manual for more information.

Abacus sends the message to create a particular server to that particular server directly after creating that server. It does this from all existing servers to increase the chances of this message getting through as it is of critical importance that this is the first message to get there.

Unfortunately if this should fail it will mean that there is no way to ensure that it is that particular message that gets re-sent (well, not that I'm aware off — other than to perhaps connect a priority to the NoAcks). Consequently the servers that are up will tend to send some other message upon reconnect. There are two possibly ways to "fix" this.

listitem.para: Delete the records from PeerMessageNoAck that refers to PeerMessage records earlier than that of the addserver message. You need to know exactly what the message id is for this to work. This can be done on a live running server. If you only had one server up and running, you need to put these records back when you are done. This can be done with the SQL statement:

screen.userinput: INSERT INTO PeerMessageNoAck SELECT \ server_id, message_id, server, 0 FROM PeerMessage;

listitem.para: where server is the numeric id of the server to be added. This will cause too many messages to be resent, but your server will be up.

You can put a record into the Server table on the affected server, i.e., the one that does not want to initialise. This record needs to contain the correct name and ID of the server. This part can be done on a running server. The processing of the addserver message will fail. This is non-critical (in this case). Shut down the server, delete the added record and restart the abacus daemon. All should now be well.
